link.title: A time to speak up: Community leaders share messages on coronavirus crisis - News - The Topeka Capital-Journal - Topeka, KS

meta.name: description
meta.content: What do you want to tell people at this crucial time in our community?The Topeka Capital-Journal posed that question to more than 20 community leaders this past week while asking them to limit their message to 50 words or less. Here is what they said:Tiffany Anderson, superintendent, Topeka USD 501“In times of adversity, we can lead, show compassion and demonstrate love in action. Thank you for leading and thank you for serving as we keep our community safe and healthy. Our positive,

"twitterID": "@timhrenchir", "twitterURL": "http://www.twitter.com/timhrenchir" } ] , "pubDateWeekday": "Saturday", "pubDate": "Mar 21, 2020 at 6:41 PM", "pubDateFormat": { "yyyy-mm-dd": "2020-03-21", "yyyy-mm-dd hh:mm:ss": "2020-03-21 18:41:46", "yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss": "2020-03-21T23:41:46+0000", "timeZone:yyyymmddThh:mm:ssZ": "20200322T00:41:46Z", "yyyymmddThh:mm:ssZ": "20200321T18:41:46Z" }, "modDate": "", "isoPubDate": "20200321184146", "isoModDate": "", "link": "https://www.cjonline.com/news/20200321/time-to-speak-up-community-leaders-share-messages-on-coronavirus-crisis", "shareLink": "localLink":"https://www.cjonline.com/news/20200321/time-to-speak-up-community-leaders-share-messages-on-coronavirus-crisis", "staticLink":"https://www.cjonline.com/article/20200321/NEWS/200329744", "thumbnail":{ "link":"https://www.cjonline.com/apps/pbcsi.dll/bilde?Site=KS&Date=20200321&Category=NEWS&ArtNo=200329744&Ref=AR" }, "track": { "articlePath": "/article/20200321/NEWS/200329744", "authorPath": "/author: /A time to speak up: Community leaders share messages on coronavirus crisis/20200321/200329744" }, "metered": false, "priority": "", "category": "News", "taxonomies": ["Community","Carousel / Featured","Happening Now","Coronavirus"], "gh_keywords": [], "keywords": ["Community","Carousel / Featured","Happening Now","Coronavirus"], "banner": "", "bannerLink": "", "viafouraUniqueID":"art-E9803E9B-80B7-4C22-BD9B-B4BCE26EA9A6-pub5035", "newsletterForm": true, "moreNewslettersLink": "http://myprofile.cjonline.com/", "googleIndexDisable":false, "body": [ "
What do you want to tell people at this crucial time in our community?
The Topeka Capital-Journal posed that question to more than 20 community leaders this past week while asking them to limit their message to 50 words or less. Here is what they said:
Tiffany Anderson, superintendent, Topeka USD 501
\"In times of adversity, we can lead, show compassion and demonstrate love in action. Thank you for leading and thank you for serving as we keep our community safe and healthy. Our positive, collective energy aimed at truly being our brother's keeper will be the difference maker for us all.\"
Christy Classi, executive director of the Kansas Society of Association Executives
\"In this time of uncertainly I am struck by the power of connection and collaboration. People are working together, finding solutions and sharing resources. The ties that bind exist even when we can't share the same physical space, and these ties have proven unbreakable. We work best when we work together, even when our 'together' looks a little different.\"
Kevin Cook, Shawnee County commissioner
\"The past several weeks have provided stories of dismay, despair and human kindness. I challenge all to be remembered for your story of kindness. Fear of the unknown can bring out the worst in any person; we must not let fear be our narrative. Let kindness be your legacy.\"
Cain Davis, chairman of the Strategic Leadership Academy
\"We should remember that U.S. citizens are overcomers who excel during difficult times (illnesses, wars, etc.), willing to put our differences behind us, while jointly and courageously defeating the challenge. We should pray and support others, especially those affected by the virus and those on the front lines. Others should use this time to love on family.\"
Neil Dobler, Topeka City Council member
\"Coming out of this crisis as a strong community depends on our ability to take care of each other. It is time to set aside those things that divide us and focus on the things that unite us — caring, compassion and charity — and practice those long after COVID-19 is just a memory.\"
Spencer Duncan, Topeka City Council member
\"Please follow health warnings and guidelines. Stay in and away from groups as much as possible. If you have neighbors or family in need, ensure they get help. It's not an overreaction to take care of yourself, follow guidelines and be cautious. You are our priority at the city and every action taken is about keeping you safe.\"
Tony Emerson, Topeka City Council member
\"This is a very tough time, especially for our small businesses and their employees. We need to remember that and 'Shop Local' when this crisis has passed. There are dark days ahead, but these are the times that bring out the best in America. We will get through this together.\"
Cody Foster, Advisors Excel owner and founder
\"Be thinking about ways you can help support — in whatever way that is: small, medium or large — some of these groups that are really being impacted by the decisions that are being made. Those include our people who are homeless, our kids who are out of school and maybe depend on school for a lot of things, and our local small businesses and the people employed by those businesses, who are being laid off like crazy right now because of some of the steps that have been taken.\"
Barry Feaker, Topeka Rescue Mission executive director
\"What comes to mind in these uncertain times are the words, 'no retreat, no regrets.' With God's grace, along with our community's faithful support and prayers, the incredible team at the Topeka Rescue Mission will remain at their posts throughout this war for our community's most vulnerable men, women and children.\"
Karen Hiller, Topeka City Council member
\"I would encourage everyone to continue keeping family, friends and colleagues safe. At the same time, I want to celebrate and encourage continuing the great positive spirit we have seen — rallying resources, supporting small businesses, encouraging each other. Together, we are doing this. #TopekaProud\"
Michael Lesser, Topeka City Council member
\"During this difficult time I ask that you be kind, patient and thoughtful to each other, try to shop local if possible, and simply look out for one another. I am not an expert in epidemiology or disaster response; so I won't try to be. We have very capable individuals leading these efforts in our state and city for which I am truly grateful. I am reminded of a quote from one of my heroes, Sen. Bob Dole: \"As long as there are only three to four people on the Senate floor, the country is in good hands. It's only when you have 50 to 60 in the Senate that you want to be concerned.\" I'm going to get out if the way and let the experts and professionals lead us through these trying times. I am prepared and ready to help create policy, and assist our community when it is time for me to do so.\"
Aaron Mays, Shawnee County commissioner
\"Government officials are working hard and taking the necessary measures to slow the spread of this pandemic. While the circumstances are challenging, we have a genuine opportunity to evaluate our processes, priorities and preparedness. Your community leaders will continue collaborating to find innovative ways to address the challenges facing families and businesses in Shawnee County.\"
Scott McWilliams, superintendent of Auburn-Washburn USD 437
\"Students, we miss you tremendously! Please be safe and healthy during this unprecedented time. Use social media in a positive and friendly way to stay connected with friends, and if you must be out, practice social distancing. We are still here for you and care greatly about your health and overall well-being. Let's remain engaged and move through this together!\"
Dene' Moser, president/CEO of the Kansas Children's Discovery Center
\"Play is powerful. Children need play to imagine, create and grow their minds in order to reduce stress and inspire joy. The Discovery Center, as a nonprofit children's museum, continues to be committed to helping kids and families grow and learn through play, offering virtual learning activities and fun online.\"
Hannah Naeger, Topeka City Council member
\"It is so important to remember the positive impact we can have on our community. Limit your physical contact with others and your time in public places. Wash your hands often and keep yourself healthy. By making these sacrifices now, we can be healthier and stronger in the future.\"
Marsha Pope, Topeka Community Foundation
\"Loving Humankind\" is the definition of philanthropy. As we navigate our response to this virus, philanthropy remains the answer. Let's continue choosing others over self; hope over worry; grace over impatience; generosity over self-interest; and faith over fear. We love our community and stand with you.\"
Bill Riphahn, Shawnee County Commission chairman
\"In the midst of facing this pandemic that has upheaved normalcy, consider that our heroes are now scientists who are working 24-7 to beat this thing, emergency and medical personnel who daily put themselves at great risk, and even the solid waste workers who, at a time we all obsess with avoiding germs, make sure our trash is picked up. I commend our city and county government staff for creativity and diligence in keeping things going.\"
Lisa Stubbs, relationship manager for Security Benefit and former Topeka City Council member
\"Topekans are an amazing group of people. We always take care of each other. This is no different. Please follow all guidance on social distancing and illness prevention. Find new ways to keep connected with friends, neighbors and family. Remember to shop local. Celebrate your blessings. We will get through this together!\"
Jenny Torrence, business owner
The world always has its way of teaching us and making us slow down. As unwelcome, unpleasant and terrifying as it may be, we need to see the beauty in humanity as we are all rallying together as one town, state, country and world. We may believe differently, but this virus teaches us we all breathe and struggle the same regardless of who we are. Love one another and be kind. ❤️ Jenny
Christina Valdivia-Alcala, Topeka City Council member
\"We will get through this. We are being asked to change our day-to-day lives in ways we are unaccustomed to. Social distancing is imperative. Some may feel the burdens and shifts more deeply than others. Help each other when you can. Reach out to elders by phone or social media. Right now we all need to be proactive. Your role is crucial.\"
Stephen Wade, publisher of The Topeka Capital-Journal
\"Verify your information! During these scary times, The Topeka Capital-Journal, WIBW-TV and KSNT-TV are all working hard to share timely and accurate information. Please be wary of 'I've heard' rumors on social media. The ugly martial law rumor is a perfect example of why one needs to listen to a trusted source for information.\"
Keith Warta, president of Bartlett & West and Momentum 2022 tri-chair
\"Our community has come so far in the last few years and it's disheartening to see the impact that COVID-19 is currently having on local businesses and scary to think of the health consequences ahead of us. I realize, however, that because of what's happened in the last three to four years, we are in a better position to weather this storm than we've ever been.\"" ],"wordCount":1565,"relatedContent": {"items": [ { "type": "mainImage", "view": false, "placement": false, "items": [ { "link": "https://www.cjonline.com/storyimage/KS/20200321/NEWS/200329744/AR/0/AR-200329744.jpg", "orientation": "L", "title": "", "credit": "", "caption": "Tiffany Anderson. form.name: siteSearchForm

div.h1: A time to speak up: Community leaders share messages on coronavirus crisis

div.p: What do you want to tell people at this crucial time in our community?

br.p: The Topeka Capital-Journal posed that question to more than 20 community leaders this past week while asking them to limit their message to 50 words or less. Here is what they said:
Tiffany Anderson, superintendent, Topeka USD 501

“In times of adversity, we can lead, show compassion and demonstrate love in action. Thank you for leading and thank you for serving as we keep our community safe and healthy. Our positive, collective energy aimed at truly being our brother’s keeper will be the difference maker for us all.”
Christy Classi, executive director of the Kansas Society of Association Executives

“In this time of uncertainly I am struck by the power of connection and collaboration. People are working together, finding solutions and sharing resources. The ties that bind exist even when we can’t share the same physical space, and these ties have proven unbreakable. We work best when we work together, even when our ’together’ looks a little different.“
Kevin Cook, Shawnee County commissioner

“The past several weeks have provided stories of dismay, despair and human kindness. I challenge all to be remembered for your story of kindness. Fear of the unknown can bring out the worst in any person; we must not let fear be our narrative. Let kindness be your legacy.”
Cain Davis, chairman of the Strategic Leadership Academy

“We should remember that U.S. citizens are overcomers who excel during difficult times (illnesses, wars, etc.), willing to put our differences behind us, while jointly and courageously defeating the challenge. We should pray and support others, especially those affected by the virus and those on the front lines. Others should use this time to love on family.”
Neil Dobler, Topeka City Council member

“Coming out of this crisis as a strong community depends on our ability to take care of each other. It is time to set aside those things that divide us and focus on the things that unite us — caring, compassion and charity — and practice those long after COVID-19 is just a memory.”
Spencer Duncan, Topeka City Council member

“Please follow health warnings and guidelines. Stay in and away from groups as much as possible. If you have neighbors or family in need, ensure they get help. It’s not an overreaction to take care of yourself, follow guidelines and be cautious. You are our priority at the city and every action taken is about keeping you safe.”
Tony Emerson, Topeka City Council member

“This is a very tough time, especially for our small businesses and their employees. We need to remember that and ’Shop Local’ when this crisis has passed. There are dark days ahead, but these are the times that bring out the best in America. We will get through this together.”
Cody Foster, Advisors Excel owner and founder

“Be thinking about ways you can help support — in whatever way that is: small, medium or large — some of these groups that are really being impacted by the decisions that are being made. Those include our people who are homeless, our kids who are out of school and maybe depend on school for a lot of things, and our local small businesses and the people employed by those businesses, who are being laid off like crazy right now because of some of the steps that have been taken.”
Barry Feaker, Topeka Rescue Mission executive director

“What comes to mind in these uncertain times are the words, ’no retreat, no regrets.’ With God’s grace, along with our community’s faithful support and prayers, the incredible team at the Topeka Rescue Mission will remain at their posts throughout this war for our community’s most vulnerable men, women and children.”
Karen Hiller, Topeka City Council member

“I would encourage everyone to continue keeping family, friends and colleagues safe. At the same time, I want to celebrate and encourage continuing the great positive spirit we have seen — rallying resources, supporting small businesses, encouraging each other. Together, we are doing this. #TopekaProud“
Michael Lesser, Topeka City Council member

“During this difficult time I ask that you be kind, patient and thoughtful to each other, try to shop local if possible, and simply look out for one another. I am not an expert in epidemiology or disaster response; so I won’t try to be. We have very capable individuals leading these efforts in our state and city for which I am truly grateful. I am reminded of a quote from one of my heroes, Sen. Bob Dole: “As long as there are only three to four people on the Senate floor, the country is in good hands. It’s only when you have 50 to 60 in the Senate that you want to be concerned.” I’m going to get out if the way and let the experts and professionals lead us through these trying times. I am prepared and ready to help create policy, and assist our community when it is time for me to do so.“
Aaron Mays, Shawnee County commissioner

“Government officials are working hard and taking the necessary measures to slow the spread of this pandemic. While the circumstances are challenging, we have a genuine opportunity to evaluate our processes, priorities and preparedness. Your community leaders will continue collaborating to find innovative ways to address the challenges facing families and businesses in Shawnee County.”
Scott McWilliams, superintendent of Auburn-Washburn USD 437

“Students, we miss you tremendously! Please be safe and healthy during this unprecedented time. Use social media in a positive and friendly way to stay connected with friends, and if you must be out, practice social distancing. We are still here for you and care greatly about your health and overall well-being. Let's remain engaged and move through this together!”
Dene’ Moser, president/CEO of the Kansas Children’s Discovery Center

“Play is powerful. Children need play to imagine, create and grow their minds in order to reduce stress and inspire joy. The Discovery Center, as a nonprofit children’s museum, continues to be committed to helping kids and families grow and learn through play, offering virtual learning activities and fun online.”
Hannah Naeger, Topeka City Council member

“It is so important to remember the positive impact we can have on our community. Limit your physical contact with others and your time in public places. Wash your hands often and keep yourself healthy. By making these sacrifices now, we can be healthier and stronger in the future.”
Marsha Pope, Topeka Community Foundation

“Loving Humankind” is the definition of philanthropy. As we navigate our response to this virus, philanthropy remains the answer. Let’s continue choosing others over self; hope over worry; grace over impatience; generosity over self-interest; and faith over fear. We love our community and stand with you.“
Bill Riphahn, Shawnee County Commission chairman

“In the midst of facing this pandemic that has upheaved normalcy, consider that our heroes are now scientists who are working 24-7 to beat this thing, emergency and medical personnel who daily put themselves at great risk, and even the solid waste workers who, at a time we all obsess with avoiding germs, make sure our trash is picked up. I commend our city and county government staff for creativity and diligence in keeping things going.”
Lisa Stubbs, relationship manager for Security Benefit and former Topeka City Council member

“Topekans are an amazing group of people. We always take care of each other. This is no different. Please follow all guidance on social distancing and illness prevention. Find new ways to keep connected with friends, neighbors and family. Remember to shop local. Celebrate your blessings. We will get through this together!”
Jenny Torrence, business owner

The world always has its way of teaching us and making us slow down. As unwelcome, unpleasant and terrifying as it may be, we need to see the beauty in humanity as we are all rallying together as one town, state, country and world. We may believe differently, but this virus teaches us we all breathe and struggle the same regardless of who we are. Love one another and be kind. ❤️ Jenny
Christina Valdivia-Alcala, Topeka City Council member

“We will get through this. We are being asked to change our day-to-day lives in ways we are unaccustomed to. Social distancing is imperative. Some may feel the burdens and shifts more deeply than others. Help each other when you can. Reach out to elders by phone or social media. Right now we all need to be proactive. Your role is crucial.”
Stephen Wade, publisher of The Topeka Capital-Journal

“Verify your information! During these scary times, The Topeka Capital-Journal, WIBW-TV and KSNT-TV are all working hard to share timely and accurate information. Please be wary of ’I’ve heard’ rumors on social media. The ugly martial law rumor is a perfect example of why one needs to listen to a trusted source for information.“
Keith Warta, president of Bartlett & West and Momentum 2022 tri-chair

“Our community has come so far in the last few years and it’s disheartening to see the impact that COVID-19 is currently having on local businesses and scary to think of the health consequences ahead of us. I realize, however, that because of what’s happened in the last three to four years, we are in a better position to weather this storm than we’ve ever been.”
